loans.name: Mayah

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Mayah. He is married and has 3 children, ages 12, 8, and 6. 

In 2006, Mayah established his beverage business. He began his business because he wants to generate funds to further his education and that is his only source of income. Working 7 days a week and 20 hours a day, he earns about 1,200,000 SLL every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL in order to buy soft drinks, stout, Maltina and parrot brand drinks. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 200,000 SLL. 

In the future, Mayah plans to further his education, take good care of his parent and to give his children a quality education. The persistent increase in the general price level is his major business challenge. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, stout, Maltina and parrot drinks for his business

loans.name: Hieng

texts.en: Both Mrs. Hieng and her husband support their family by fishing in the Basaac River.  They earn around $6 a day.  They have two children.  In order to better support their family, they would like to request a loan of $400 to purchase a net and a machine to haul it.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net and net hauling machine

loans.name: Ma. Emma

texts.en:
Ma. Emma works hard to support her family. Ma. Emma is married and has a business selling vegetables in the Philippines.

Ma. Emma requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall.

Ma. Emma has been in this business for 20 years.

In the future, Ma. Emma would like to save enough to build a new store.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes, sheets, gift items and other things.

loans.name: Hue

texts.en:
Hue was born in 1976. She lives in Xom Huong village, Co Loa commune. She is married with two children. Her husband is a driver, and she has a general store. 

She has a participated in SEDA since 2004. The last time, she borrowed 8,066,000 Vietnamese dong (VND). This time, she would like to borrow 9,374,000 VND to invest in her general store(to buy more chairs, tables, goods,et).

loans.use: to invest in her general store(to buy more chairs, tables, goods,et).

loans.name: Doris Elizabeth

texts.es:
Doris, vive con sus dos hijas gemelas de 3 años, es viuda hace tres años murió el esposo, desde hace 8 años compro el negocio de la nevería: sorbetes, paletas, vasitos, sórbeletas, vende todos los días de lunes a domingo.
El préstamo lo utilizara para comprar más mercadería (sorbetes de varios sabores) y de esa forma aumentar  las ventas y obtener buenos resultados y dar mejor atención a sus clientes con productos variados.
El sueño de Doris, es que su negocio crezca y darle una mejor vida a sus hijas, ya que ellas están creciendo y necesitan de ella.
texts.en:
Doris lives with her 3-year-old twin daughters.  She’s a widow; her husband died three years ago.  She bought an ice cream shop 8 years ago.  She sells sorbets, popsicles, ice cream cones, etc. every day from Monday through Sunday.

She will use the loan to buy more merchandise (various flavored sorbets) to increase sales and obtain good results and to provide better customer service with a variety of products.

Doris’ dream is that the business grows to provide her daughters with a better life since they are growing and need her.

loans.use: to buy assorted sorbets.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel used his previous loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy charcoal. He generated a lot of income from his business. With the increased income, he was able to raise his living standard.

Now, Samuel wants to open a salon and a barber shop, so he has requested a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings.

loans.use: To open a barber shop and a salon

loans.name: Turdiali

texts.ru: Турдиали на протяжении многих лет занимается бизнесом. Он опытный дехканин. Он занимается выращиванием сельхозкультур. Труд на земле очень тяжелый требует усилий. Но для этого нужны средства для покупки минеральных удобрений и семян. Кредит он хотел бы получить для посева озимых и уборке урожая. В настоящее время он обучает своему дехканскому ремеслу своих сыновей. Он знает, что земля всегда приносит хорошие плоды если ты потрудишься.
texts.en: Turdiali has been involved in business for many years.  He is an experienced farmer.  He is involved in growing agricultural crops.  Working on land is a hard labor that requires a lot of effort and funds to buy mineral fertilizers and seeds.  Turdiali wants to obtain this loan to plant winter crops and gather his harvest.  Currently, Turdiali is teaching the farming business to his sons.  He knows that the land will always provide a good harvest if you work hard enough.

loans.use: to plant winter crops and gather the harvest

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
Adelina is 46 years old. She is married and has three children. Adelina has a "sari-sari store" (variety store) that sells products which are used daily like bath soap and toothpaste. Her store also sells canned goods, biscuits and other usual kitchen needs like salt, sugar, cooking oil. She has had this business for five years. 

She requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy additional stocks for her store like additional canned goods, biscuits, toothpaste, bath soap and other kitchen needs.

Adelina joined as a member of HSPFI in the year 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy products such as bath soap, shampoo, toothpaste, and other kitchen needs to sell

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is a married woman with two children, all of whom have graduated from school.  She owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a cosmetic and clothes selling business.  Zainabu sells door to door to her neighbors and to passersby.  She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.  Her dream is to become a retail supplier of beauty products and clothes in the future.

With a Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase beauty products like facial creams, body lotions and bundles of clothes to sell during festive seasons. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products like facial creams, body lotions and bundles of clothes to sell during festive seasons.

loans.name: Evans Tokali

texts.en: Evans is a 22 year old single man. He describes himself as social and welcoming. He operates a retail store where he sells household products. He has been involved in this business for 1 year. His business is located in Mishomoroni, a suburb of Mombasa, and he has both new and returning customers. He says his biggest business challenge is price fluctuation of the goods he sells. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more household products to sell. His business goal is to be a wholesaler within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy more household products to sell.

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr:
Akossiwwa est une femme âgé(e) de âge ans. Elle est mariée à un déclarant en douanes et est mère de 03 enfants.
Akossiwwa travaille comme revendeuse d’ignames depuis 1991. Elle achète à l’intérieur du pays et vend à ses clients dans un marché de la place.
Akossiwwa a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des ignames.
texts.en:
Akossiwwa is woman married to a customs agent. She has three children. Since 1991, she's been reselling yams. She purchases her supplies in the interior of the country, and resells to her customers at a market in her town.

Akossiwwa is seeking her first loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, in order to buy yams.

loans.use: to buy and resell yams

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en:
Sokheng is a 24-year-old mother of 2 dependent children. She has been working on her rice paddy field and cassava plantation for 7 years in a village in the Ponhea Krek district. Sometimes she works for others to raise additional income. She currently earns only about US $3 per day from her business.

Sokheng is applying for her first loan with VisionFund. She will use it to buy cassava seedlings and fertilizer for her plantation. She hopes this loan enables her to produce more crop yield and increase her income to feed her family better.

loans.use: to buy cassava seedlings and fertilizer for her plantation

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard has been farming for 5 years, and he produces maize and eggs, which he sells to the local market. He also operates a motorcycle business in his home area of Kitale, Western Kenya. He is 41 and married with 4 children who are all attending school.

Benard has made a loan request of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. He says the income will help him to educate the children as well as to expand his farming business. He is planning on having five dairy cows on his farm.

He notes that animal disease remains his major challenge.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is a 58-year-old married woman from Trinidad, Bohol. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store business where she sells items like canned goods, cooking oil, vinegar and soy sauce. Carmelita also works at their rice farm. She helps her husband grow and sell rice.

Carmelita has requested this loan to buy fertilizers and more items to sell such as canned goods, sugar, soap and shampoo. Carmelita hopes that through her income, she will be able to sustain her children's education and improve their living situation.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and more items to sell such as canned goods, sugar, soap and shampoo.

loans.name: Raheli

texts.en: Raheli, 38, is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past three years, she has operated a tailoring business from her home, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She dreams of establishing a boutique business in the future. With her KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase cloth, sewing threads and embroidery for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth, sewing threads and embroidery for her business.

loans.name: Abagambakamu Women Gp Kabata Kisomoro Group

texts.en: Regina is a member of Abagambakamu Women Gp Kabata Kisomoro, where each member guarantees the others to get a loan. She is a retailer and at the same time grows maize and beans. She faces challenges of limited capital and price fluctuation. However, she has hopes of having enough income and expanding her business to new areas. Regina needs a loan to buy beans, soap, cooking oil and paraffin to sell.

loans.use: to buy beans, soap, cooking oil and paraffin to sell.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
From the countryside near the Kaplamai, Kitale area of Kenya is a jobless man-turned farmer named James and his family of two lovely children. He is a hardworking man and aggressive with the principle of truth on his lips; he is honest and faithful to what he does and what he says. 

Kaplamai in the local dialect means valley. In this valley are a people who, in their totality, constitute wrenching statistics. Hardcore poverty pervades every homestead, yet every day when you look beyond the numbers, you will see a sea of people: a sea of about two thousand bright, vibrant, open faces, searching and yearning for the opportunity to live a life of dignity and respect. They have the conviction that it’s possible. 

Armed with this conviction, James has kept hope and has been toiling on his farm for the past seven years. His primary sources of income have been milk, poultry and some “side hustles” he does to supplement the meager income he earns from farming. The Kaplamai area has only one diesel posho mill that serves a sea of people but the mill keeps breaking down; hence farmers are not able to grind their maize. James intends to change this and is requesting a loan to buy an electric posho mill, which will grind corn or maize into flour. 

Maize meal is very common in Kenya and is a staple food for many communities. Many Kenyan families consume the maize product “ugali“ (hard porridge) regularly. The market usually provides sifted flour, but the cost is higher because of the sifting and packaging. Cheaper flour can be obtained by milling the maize directly using a posho mill. Through this loan, James will be able to grind maize faster because he will use an electric posho mill. Cases of breakdown will be long history because electric posho mills are more reliable. 

This loan will assist James to permanently change his life and achieve his life mission of driving economic development and poverty alleviation in communities in arid and semi-arid areas. Profits from the posho mill will be used to comfortably repay the loan, which James promises to fully repay on time. In the next two years, James sees himself as a very established businessman who will be running more than one posho mill in his remote village. James patiently waits for your kindness.

loans.use: To buy an electric posho mill

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve on the computer bureau.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sewing machines for expanding and relocating her tailoring business.

loans.name: Ramzia

texts.en:
Ramzia lives in District 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is an uneducated woman. She is married and she and she wants to help her husband, who is a plumber. He wants to open a shop in main city of Kabul because lots of the construction companies are there who always need plumbers. His wants to take the loan to help her husband make a good life for themselves. She is happy to be able to help her husband.

Note the picture featured in this business profile is the husband of entrepreneur. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable for some people to post a picture of a woman to the Internet. The loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Buy plumbing supplies

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en: Charlotte T. B. is a single woman with no children.  She has 12 years of work experience in selling ladies’ fashion and cosmetic products. She was a student before starting her business, but because of financial problems she didn’t complete her education (business administration). She wants to purchase goods in bulk. She is lives with her 2 sisters in a small apartment in Yopougon, a township in the north of Abidjan. She is very ambitious and would like to open a big store. She used to buy her goods in Accra, Ghana.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetic products

loans.name: Vunegho

texts.en:
Born in 1962, K. is a widow with six children. Her difficulties in life stem from the fact that she has no relatives to help her take care of her six children. After the death of her husband, she could not pay bills, pay school fees, or buy other things her children need for school so she sought help from GHAPE. Here, she was given her first loan of $40 with which she raised money to pay school fees for some of her children.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to sale fresh ground nuts, roast corn, and other food items along the roadside where there are many passerbys. The profit will be used to continue educating her children and to increase her business. She plans to pay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of groundnuts, bananas, plantains, corn, and garri etc

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita S. H. belongs to the village bank “Arco Iris,” which means “rainbow” in Spanish.

Margarita is what in Spanish is known as a "ferriante,” which means she supplies products in bulk to the community every given number of days each week. With her warm and youthful smile, she explains that three times each week she must rent a car to drive up to three hours outside city limits into the rural “campo” of Ayacucho, Peru. There she buys cheese, beef, and pork. With these supplies, she returns to the city to sell her fresh products door-to-door. Margarita began business as a “ferriante” some 22 years ago when she married her husband and started a new family.

In addition to her work supplying fresh food products to the community three times each week, Margarita also has a business in selling “leña,” or firewood, to the women in her neighborhood. Firewood is the principal means of heating homes and cooking food in this area, and everyday Margarita’s neighbors come to her to buy their daily supply.

Margarita says she is very grateful to be a part of her village bank because it has taught her how to save the profits she makes from both businesses. When her husband fell ill recently, she was able to use the savings she has been storing in the bank to pay for his operation. She is asking for a $900 loan, which she will be able to put back into all aspects of her businesses, including the purchase of greater quantities of products and pay for transportation to the countryside to make these purchases.

loans.use: She is asking for a $900 loan, which she will be able to put back into all aspects of her businesses, including the purchase of greater quantities of products and to pay for transportation to the countryside to make these purchases.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Mrs. Rita O. is 40 years old, is married with 3 children, and lives in Benin City. She has a store where she sells wrappers. She worked with someone for 3 months to learn the business, and then started her own business in 2006.

Mrs. O. requests a loan of $875 to buy more wrappers and clothes to sell. She is a member of LAPO.

loans.use: Buy more wrappers and clothes to sell

loans.name: Salem

texts.en:
Salem lives in the region of Nabatieh, in South Lebanon. He is 35 years old. Salem fixes cars' steering wheels. He also sells wheels and offers wheel maintenance services.

Salem needs $1200 to purchase the needed material for his business sustainability and development. He is planning to get married and the additional income will help him pay for the wedding expenses.

loans.use: To purchase the needed material

loans.name: Ati

texts.en: Ati, 36, was selling vegetables for a living but this business was not growing very well because she had run out of capital. Now she and her husband, P., produce bamboo matting and earn about $6 a day; their income depends on the amount of orders they can fill. She is asking for a loan of $75 to continue her vegetable business and bamboo matting. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her business capital

loans.name: C. Nabuti A(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Hadija N.. She sells matooke (plantain bananas used for cooking) and is requesting a loan to improve her busines. Hadija is 30 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, Hadija hopes to be able to re-invest in her business.

Hadija is joined in her small group by Annet N., Scovia Nanyango, Christine M., and Polline N.. Annet N. sells fresh food and wants to increase her inventory. Scovia Nanyango makes and sells fried snacks and wants a loan to add to her business. Christine M. raises poultry and wants a loan to purchase poultry feed. Polline N. sells matooke and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more bunches of matooke (plantain bananas) to sell

loans.name: Tranquilino

texts.es:
Tranquilino is 60 years old. He has been married for 32 years to Dora and they have raised , with a lot of love, 6 children together. The children are between the ages of 15 and 30 years old. The older ones work in different fields such as computers, technical and public transportation and one of them is an obstetrician. The two younger ones are twins and they go to high school.

Tranquilino is the owner of a book store which he's owned for the past 20 years. He used to work at a gas station, but his enterprising spirit led him to a seek some financial help to start his own business. Little by little, his business grew and with more loans he was able to purchase more inventory for his bookstore.

With time and with perseverance from him and his family, he was able to move ahead and he now owns a beautiful home. Beside the bookstore, he also owns a food stand where he sells fast food which is run by his wife.

Since it's back to school time and because he wants to make sure his bookstore has all the inventory needed for school, he's requesting a loan to purchase school supplies such as books, notepads, pens and pencils, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

Tranquilino tiene 60 años y está casado hace 32 años con Dora, juntos han criado con mucho amor a 6 hijos. La edad de ellos oscila entre los 15 y 30 años de edad. Los hijos mayores ya trabajan en distintas profesiones como: técnicos en informática, chofer de transporte público, uno de ellos es obstetra. Y los dos hijos menores son mellizos y aún van a la secundaria.

Tranquilino posee una librería, comenta que abrió su librería hace 20 años pero que anteriormente trabajaba en un surtidor pero su espíritu emprendedor lo llevo a solicitar créditos con los que pudo montar su propio negocio. Poco a poco fue agrandando el mismo y con otros préstamos que fue adquiriendo iba surtiendo cada vez más.

Con el tiempo y esfuerzo tanto de él como el de su familia logró salir adelante y ahora ya cuenta con una hermosa casa, fruto de su esfuerzo y perseverancia. Además de la librería, también tiene un copetín donde vende todo tipo de comidas rápidas y que es administrado por el y su esposa, la misma cuenta con una gran afluencia de clientes.

En esta oportunidad necesita un préstamo para la compra de artículos escolares como: libros, cuadernos, lápices, pinceles, etc. Debido a que se han iniciado las clases y desea surtir mejor su librería.

loans.use: To purchase school supplies

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene A. is a 33-year-old, single mother of three children, all of whom live with her. Because she is the only one responsible for her three sons, she knows that she needs to work very hard in order to raise them and to provide them a good education.

A few years ago, Irene started working with her aunt as a seamstress. In doing so, she gained invaluable experience, and she learned how to properly use the sewing machines. In addition, she saved a considerable amount of money from her work with her aunt; consequently, she invested her savings by purchasing sewing machines and raw materials and was thus able to open her own sewing shop.

Irene is most interested in fashion design, and her biggest dream is to design different types of clothes and to sell them in stores.

She makes beautiful cardigans, sheets, pillows, and other such items. In order to meet her customers' demands, she is seeking a loan to buy raw materials such as fabrics, bottoms, and threads to produce her goods.

loans.use: To meet her customers' demands by purchasing additional raw materials (e.g., fabrics, bottoms, and threads) so that she may continue to supply her products.

loans.name: Binta

texts.fr:
Binta Koné is a 26-year-old woman and the mother of a 3-year-old girl. She lives with her mother and her brothers and sisters in the family of their deceased father. Following his death and some disappointments in life, Ms. Binta decided to drop out of school at age 15 in order to earn money to help her family. She has been trying different businesses for years but without success, due in particular to meager working capital.

With the arrival of the cellular phone in Mali, she decided to start a phone booth (a "tele-center"). This is why, after some reflection, she has decided to take out a loan with Soro Yiriwaso in order to buy in quantity prepaid phone cards in Bamako for retail sale in Bougouni.

Her customers are composed of local people but also vendors and travelers who frequent the route. The turnover of this business is very high, and she manages to realize a monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA. With this profit, she pays the interest on the loan and covers much of family expenses. Ms. Binta Koné is very satisfied and believes that Soro Yiriwaso has contributed to resolving certain difficulties her family had been confronted with.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Mademoiselle Binta Koné est une femme de 26 ans et mère d’une fille de 3 ans. Elle vit avec sa mère et ses autres frères et soeurs dans la famille de leur défunt père. Suite au décès de son père et certaines déceptions de la vie, Mademoiselle Binta décida d’abandonner l’école à l’âge de 15 ans pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus pour aider sa famille. Elle a tenté pendant des années différentes activités sans succès en raison surtout de la faiblesse de son fonds de commerce.

Avec l’avènement du téléphone cellulaire au Mali, elle décida de faire une cabine téléphonique (un télé centre).. C’est ainsi qu’après réflexion, elle décida de prendre un prêt auprès de Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter des cartes de recharges prépayées à Bamako en quantité pour venir les vendre en détail à Bougouni.

Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale mais aussi de forains et voyageurs qui fréquentent le trajet. La rotation de cette activité est très élevée et elle arrive à réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice, elle paie les intérêts du prêt et contribue fortement aux dépenses familiales. Mademoiselle Binta Koné est très satisfaite et estime que Soro Yiriwaso a contribué à résoudre certaines difficultés auxquelles sa famille était confrontée.

loans.use: To buy and sell retail prepaid phone cards

loans.name: Raisa

texts.en: Raisa E. is a 52-year-old woman who has owned her grocery store in the Internally Displaced People Settlement of Imishli since 1998. This store is the only source of income for her family. She is director and sales manager at the same time. Her income is just enough to cover family needs but not enough to expand her business. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to increase the number of grocery products in her store.

loans.use: To increase inventories of grocery products

loans.name: Kimsran

texts.en: Mrs. Kimsran D. is 32 years old and the mother of four children who are all enrolled in school.   Mrs. Kimsran D. sells fish in Preak Konlong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Sophea Koub, is a farmer. Mrs. Kimsran D. buys fish and resells them but now wants her husband to catch the fish. She requests a loan to buy a new boat to start his business. Mrs. Kimsran D. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a new boat.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: This is the second time Mr. Sao S. has sought a loan to improve his standard of living. He is a firewood seller in the village of Thlork Roling in Kampong Chhnang Province. His wife, Mrs. Horl Naom, is a farmer. On her farm, she does not have enough oxen to plow the rice field, so her husband is seeking a loan to buy one more ox to plow the field with the old one. Mr. Sao S. is 33 years old and the father of three children, one of whom is attending school while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy an ox to help plow the field

loans.name: Jamahon

texts.ru:
Косимов Джаъмахон, ему 24 лет, женат. Предпринимательством занимается пять лет и на данный момент торгует мужскими одеждами.  Торгует на рынке «Корвон» города Душанбе. В его ассортименте большой выбор спортивной одежды, футболки, трико, спортивные костюмы хлопчатобумажных и маячных материалов производство Китая и Турции. Он закупает товар у поставщиков из Китая и Турции. 
Джаъмахон хочет закупить сезонный товар и желает участвовать в программе Кива, чтоб получить денежные средства для расширения бизнеса в сумме 4000 сомони.
texts.en:
Jamahon K. is 24 years old and married. He has been an entrepreneur for five years and currently deals in men’s clothing at the Korvon market in the city of Dushanbe. His inventory includes a wide selection of sportswear, t-shirts, stretch pants, and cotton and jersey sets manufactured in China and Turkey. He buys his wares from suppliers in China and Turkey. Jamahon wants to purchase seasonal goods and wishes to participate in Kiva’s program in order to acquire the financial means to expand his business, the sum of $1175 (4000 somoni).

Translated from Russian by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seasonal sportswear

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi has been selling kanga and other fabrics in Zanzibar for five years. "Kanga" is a local fabric that is often brightly colored and can have one of a huge variety of patterns on it. They also contain a local adage written in Swahili at the bottom. Kanga is used for everything from clothing and baby slings to table cloths and sofa covers. Mwanaidi works every day from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. selling her fabrics and is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $45.

Mwanaidi is married and has four children, ages 10, 12, 14 and 16.

loans.use: To buy more kanga fabric for her shop.

loans.name: Nelly Nancy

texts.es:
La señorita Nelly tiene 42 años de edad, pertenece al  Banco Comunal Luis Alberto Sánchez II y vive en la calle Leoncio Prado 777, distrito de Moche, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta el tercer año de secundaria, pero más le gustó trabajar y ya no continuó estudiando.
Nelly vende peluches y regalitos en su casa. Como es una mujer muy trabajadora y emprendedora, incursionó en la venta de verduras y molidos en un puesto del mercado llamado La Baratura.
Con su primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas, comenzó a vender, choco tejas,  marcianos y gelatina.
Con este crédito de S/. 700, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en verduras, molidos y peluches navideños.
Nelly sueña con tener un negocio con capital propio.
texts.en:
Nelly is 42 years old, belongs to the Communal Bank “Luis Alberto Sánchez II” and lives at Leoncio Prado 777, Moche district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Peru. She completed third year of secondary school, but she liked working more so she didn’t finish her education. Nelly sells plush toys and small gifts from her home. As she is a hard working and enterprising woman, she also sells vegetables and ground spices in a stand in the La Baratura market. With her first loan for S/.300 which was repaid in 4 payrments, she began to sell gelatins, popsicles, and chocolate snacks. With this loan for S/.800, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will invest in vegetables, ground spices, and Christmas plush toys. Nelly dreams of having a business with her own capital.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy vegetables, ground spices and plus Christmas items

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric S. is a trader. He sells food in the market at Ntsiman near Elmina, and he also operates a corn mill.  His major challenge is fueling the milling machine. Eric is divorced with one child and received his education through senior high school.  

Eric has been selling food since 2006.  Eric intends to use his loan to buy more food to sell and also use part of his loan to invest in running his milling machine.  He will use the profits to pay for his child’s school fees, feed them both and also pay the utility bills. He will also use some of his profits to extend his business.

loans.use: Eric intends using the money given him to buy more foodstuffs to sell and also use part of the money to invest in the running of his milling machine.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan S. is a widowed farmer who lives in Prey Veng province, about 62 miles southeast of the Capital, Phnom Penh. She lives with her husband and five of her children. She typically earns $2 a day and is supported by two of her children who work as a tailor and a mechanic. The rest of her children are students. 

Thach Sichan, 22, is the oldest daughter and has been running a tailoring business since 2007. She is the one who most strongly supports the family expenses. On average, she earns $5 a day. To expand her daughters tailoring business, Mrs. Chan Sava is requesting a loan from Kiva to help purchase more decorative cloth and tools.

loans.use: Purchase more decorative cloth and tailoring tools.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is thirty nine years old. She is widowed and a single mother with one child who is currently in school with the help of government free and compulsory education for every child. She lives at Abofour, a farming community in the Ashanti region of Ghana. 

They say death is inevitable but Elizabeth never expected her husband would leave her so suddenly. He died out of a minor ache and he passed away when he was rushed to the hospital. Because of this, she is struggling hard to provide support for her family.
  
She sells cereals like bags of rice and wheat in the community market and she is trying to build her name in the market. However, she is still constrained with inadequate funds to make her business progress. She deems this an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use this loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc.and increase her stock of goods available for sale. She has run this business for 10 years and she has used the proceeds for her household need. She travels to Kumasi which is one the busiest market to buy  her supply of goods. 

Elizabeth belongs to a village bank called Born Again. She also hopes to receive GH¢600 to build her business by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to support her childs education. She has been encouraged to register with the health insurance to take care of the medical expenses of her family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and wheat.

loans.name: Zinaida

texts.en:
Zinaida lives in Mukachevo. She owns a small business selling household supplies in one of the local markets in her home town. Zinaida offers a very large assortment of inventory and her price range is also quite diverse. Loans that she previously received from Nadiya Ukraine promoted the growth of her business. Zinaida has been in the trade for 3 years. Currently, she has about 50,000 UAH in inventory. Her monthly income is about 3,000 UAH. 

Zinaida’s business is the only source of income for her family. Today she would like to get a loan of 5,000 UAH to buy a variety of retail items wholesale. We believe Zinaida’s focused approach to business and her diligent hard work will help her repay this loan on time and expand her business as a result.

loans.use: To purchase items for resale

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with a son. She runs a small business selling clothing for women. Her kiosk is located in one of the busiest city markets of Kherson. A beautiful array of assorted clothes attracts many customers to Irina’s kiosk. Irina has been in this business for 10 years. She has currently invested 60,000 Grivnas in merchandise. 

Irina is a hard worker and a talented manager. She has had a perfect credit history in “Nadiya Ukraine” without any defaults. She has repaid 12 previous loans without any delinquencies. Moreover, Irina is very devoted to the success of her business, and we believe she will be able to service the loan without a problem. Irina needs the loan of 9,000 Grivnas to improve her business by stocking more clothing items. The loan will help her expand her business and clientele. Moreover, this financial contribution would have a positive impact not only on her trade profitability but would also improve the economic and social situation of her family.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Lefiu

texts.en:
Lefiu T., age 38, is married and has four children. She has many years of experience selling pork buns. She sells to the villagers and the public six days per week.

This is her first loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD). SPBD loans are Lefiu’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. All of her loan will be used to maintain her business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of flour, cooking oil, yeast, baking powder and an oven.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
MARTHA O. VELAZQUES, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Talentosas”  con su local ubicado en el Jr. Salaverry Nº 597 del Distrito de Calleria; tiene 47 años, su esposo es instructor de físico culturismo tienen  01 hijo menor y 02 ya profesionales.

Hace ya 05 años que es socia de Manuela Ramos, con su primer préstamo  de S/. 300 Nuevos Soles lo utilizo para mejorar la seguridad del local donde vende licores y bebidas gaseosas.

Con este préstamo de S/.3,000.00 Nuevos Soles, piensa  mejorar la infraestructura del local así como también comprara Bebidas de todas las marcas.

Comenta: “Me Agrada la forma de trabajo de Manuela Ramos, el sistema que tiene, el orden, así como las orientaciones que dan, he puesto en práctica algunos consejos que me ayudaron a mejorar mi empresa.
texts.en:
Martha O. Velásquez belongs to the “Mujeres Talentosas” community bank. Her business is located at Jr. Salaverry Nº 597 in the Calleria district. She is 47; her husband is a body building instructor. They have one minor child; the other two are already professionals. She has been a member of Manuela Ramos for 5 years. With her first loan of 300 PEN she improved the security on the premises where she sells liquor and soft drinks. With a loan of 3,000 PEN she will improve the infrastructure of her establishment. She will also buy all brands of drinks. She says, “I like the way Manuela Ramos works: the system they have, the order, and the orientations they give. I have put into practice some of the advice; that helped me improve my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soft drinks and liquor.  Maintenance of infrastructure of her business location.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es: La señora Dominga es una cliente antigua tiene cinco niños en edad escolar, ella es migrante de la region sur del pais(Tarija) por lo tanto no tiene casa propia vive en casa alquilada, conjuntamente su esposo tienen un taller de carpinteria, así mismo la señora para ayudar en la manutencion de su familia se dedica a la elaboracion de pan y empanadas, para lo cual ella cuenta con un hornito domestico, en el que diarimente elabora panes y los distribuye diariamente en la zona sur de la ciudad de La Paz
texts.en:
Ms. Dominga is an old client who has 5 school-age children. She is a migrant from the southern region, Tarija, which is why she doesn't have her own home and has to rent. She and her husband have carpentry workshop. She also makes bread and empanadas to help maintain her family. She has a small oven that she makes breads on each day and distributes them on the south side of La Paz.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cliente invertira en la compra de materia harina y otros insumos para la elaboracion de panes

loans.name: Ho Thi

texts.en:
M. Hồ Thị is a forty years old and lives in the town of Gia Lộc.  She is married and has three school-age children.  To make a living, M. owns and operates a business running a food stall where she sells a variety of products in the local community.  M. has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately $230 a month from these activities.


In 2008, M. joined the Kiva field partner, TYM Fund, to gain access to financial services that would help improve her living situation through engaging in business activities.  M. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  M. is now requesting a new loan that will be used to invest in expanding the business.  This will be her second loan from TYM Fund.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
La señora Isabel, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Señor de Los Milagros”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad de Imicati, distrito de Yunguyo, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno. Tiene 35 años de edad, es casada y madre de 04 hijos, posee estudios de secundaria completa y vive en el Centro poblado de Villa Santa Rosa en Jr. Independencia s/n.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace casi 5 años, con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, para comprar ropa para su negocio.

Actualmente solicita un préstamo de S/. 1000.00 Nuevos soles, para comprar ropa y así aumentar el capital de su negocio de compra y venta de ropas, tiene su puesto en el mercado de Yunguyo.

Su mayor sueño es poder darles una educación a sus hijos.

A ella le gustan las facilidades de los préstamos que ofrece su Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
Isabel is a member of the communal bank "Señor de Los Milagros”, which is located in the Imicati Community, Yunguyo district, Chucuito province, department of Puno. She is 35 years old, married, and mother of 4 children. She has completed secondary studies and she lives in El Centro Poblado de Villa Santa Rosa on Jr. Independencia s/n.

She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for almost 5 years. She started with a loan of S/. 300 nuevo soles, which she used to buy clothes for her business.

Now she is requesting a loan of S/. 10000 nuevo soles to buy clothes and in this way increase working capital for her business of buying and selling clothes. Her stand is in the Yunguyo market.

Her greatest dream is to be able to provide her children with an education.

She likes the terms of credit offered by her communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Agbenike

texts.en: Agbenike makes a living selling drinks and providing office services. She is 55 years old, married and has nine children.  Agbenike has applied for this loan to buy more items to sell, and wishes to thank Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Madeleine Ngoné

texts.fr: Madeleine Ngoné âgée de 36 ans est mariée et mère de 03 enfants à sa charge. Son activité est la vente de papaye et de manioc. Elle veut renforcer son commerce. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Madeleine Ngoné, age 36, is married and the mother of three children in her care. Her business involves selling papayas and cassava. She wants to bolster her business. Her revenues enable her to improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell papayas and yuca (cassava)

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es: Jose Luis de 32 años de edad es soltero, pero vive en union libre con la mamá de niño de 4 años de edad que asiste al pre-escolar, trabaja como conductor en el MINSA del Rama con 9 años de servicio, esta solicitando refinanciamiento de su 6to credito para acondicionar un cuarto, pues habita en casa de sus padres los que le dieron para hacer un cuartito en un garaje, al cual desea quitarle los portones y levantar pared dejando espacio para hacer una puerta que de salida independiente a la calle, ademas desea cerrar una puerta que une a la sala de su mamá y de esta manera tratar de independizar a su familia.   El mayor sueño de Jose Luis es poder tener un lugar con el cual pueda estar junto a su familia con las condiciones basicas y que su hijo crezca en un ambiente alegre.
texts.en:
Jose Luis is 32 years old and single, but lives in a free union with the mother of his 4 year old child, who currently attends preschool. Jose Luis has worked as a driver for the MINSA del Rama for 9 years. He is asking for refinancing on his sixth loan so he can renovate his living quarters. He stays at his parents' house in a small room in the garage. He wants to take out the main doors and raise the walls so there is room to construct a door that leads directly to the street as well as seal the door that connects his quarters to those of his mother's in attempt to try and make his family more independent. Jose Luis' biggest dream is to be able to have a place where he can be near his family, their basic living conditions are met, and that his son grows up in a happy environment.

Translated from Spanish by Colleen Godfrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raise a wall and install a door

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
Belen G. is from the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old. Belen is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Belen owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. Belen has been in business for over 15 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Belen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Belen is requesting a loan of 2,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Belen from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of manure as fertilizer

loans.name: Jovita

texts.es: Jovita es una mujer colaboradora y trabajadora, tiene 66 años D. edad, es madre D. cinco hijos todos mayores D. edad, se dedica a la venta D. productos como abarrotes en general, artículos D. oficinas y bebidas, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo quien es jubilado D. una empresa maderera, ellos trabajan juntos en la tienda. Es socia hace siete años del Banco Comunal “La Fortaleza”,su primer préstamo fue D. 300 soles que invirtió en la compra D. gaseosas.  Ahora requiere D. un préstamo D. 1000 soles que invertirá, una parte en productos lácteos y otra parte en artículos D. oficina. La meta D. Jovita es tener una tienda mas amplia y vender artículos D. adornos para el hogar.

loans.use: comprará productos lácteos y artículos de oficina.

loans.name: Carina

texts.es:
Carina es una joven madre de 24 años, vive al lado de su esposo y sus 2 hijos. Desde niña ha trabajado arduamente siendo un valioso apoyo para sus padres en sus terrenos agrícolas. Ahora, junto con su esposo, labra sus propias tierras, cultivando maíz, papa, trigo y otros productos. Adicionalmente cría ganado ovino en un espacio que acondiciona en su misma vivienda. El deseo a futuro de Carina y de su esposo, es seguir trabajando en sus tierras y mejorar su producción agrícola.

Esta es la primera oportunidad en que tiene un crédito con MFP, ella está muy entusiasmada por conocer a fondo como funciona un banco comunal y desde ya se ha comprometido a ser responsable con sus pagos. El dinero que ahora solicita será invertido en la compra de sacos de abono para su próxima campaña de siembra.
texts.en:
Carina is a young 24 year old mother who lives with her husband and two sons. Since she was a child, she has worked very hard, being a great help to her parents in their fields. Now, with her husband, she works her own land, cultivating corn, potatoes, wheat, and other products. She also raises sheep in a place she fixed up at her house. Carina and her husband hope to continue to work their land and improve their agricultural production. This is her first opportunity for a loan with MFP, and she is excited to learn more about how her communal bank works. She has promised to be responsible with her payments. The money she is asking for will be invested in the purchase of sacks of fertilizer for her next round of planting.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer

loans.name: Sani

texts.en:
Mrs. Sani K. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishipati, Lalitpur. Sainbu-Bhaishipati is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur, and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming. Mrs. Sani K. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Utsak K., is a farmer. She has one son and one daughter. Her son took the School Leaving Certificate Exam this year, and her daughter is studying in primary school.

Mrs. Sani is engaged in selling cow’s milk. She already owns two cows, and she sells their milk in her locality. Currently, in her region, the demand for cow’s milk is increasing constantly. To meet the demand of her customers, she needs another young milk-giving cow, and she is requesting a loan of 20000 NPR to buy one.

loans.use: To purchase another young milk-giving cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply her store with merchandise

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en:
A. Uuganbayar is 28 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in Kharhorin, the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His wife is currently employed as an accountant at a local grocery shop.
Uuganbayar operates a transportation service in his town using his large van. He transports people to and from Kharhorin and Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. Uuganbayar started his business in 2003 after working as a livestock herder for three years. He has found success with his business over the years and has built up a reputation as a good and honest driver. Uuganbayar is focused on continuing to improve his business and provide a good life for his family. He hopes to use his earnings to buy a new house for them. Uuganbayar is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a new motor and heating system for his van. The picture shows Uuganbayar with his youngest child.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase a new motor and heating system for his van

loans.name: Orlith

texts.es:
Orlith tiene 58 años, está casada, vive con su esposo y su nieta, quien está estudiando.
Desde hace 15 años se dedica a la venta de comida por las tardes, ya que por las mañanas se dedica a la agricultura, siembra frutos cítricos y yuca.
Sus platos de comida los vende afuera de su vivienda en un pequeño espacio que acondicionó para la ocasión. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que muchas personas degusten de su buena sazón, y darles una buena atención es lo que más le importa a Orlith. 
Por otro lado, lo más difícil para ella es no contar con un local apropiado para sus clientes, pues para el futuro le gustaría tener su propio restaurante.

Este es su 12avo préstamo con MFP, ella es parte de un banco comunal y lo que le gusta es que las personas de su grupo son personas coordinadas y muy organizadas. Con el dinero que ahora solicita mandará a construir una “ramada” (techo hecho con madera y ramas) para protegerse de las lluvias, también comprará sillas y mesas.
texts.en:
Orlith is 58 years old, is married and lives with her husband and granddaughter who is a student. For fifteen years, she has been dedicated to selling food in the evenings, since, in the mornings, she is dedicated to farming, sowing citrus fruits and yucca. She sells her dishes outside her home in a small spot that is prime for the job. What she likes most about her job is that many people enjoy her work and giving them good service is what is most important to Orlith. At the same time, what is most difficult for her is not having a suitable space for her customers. So, in the future, she would like to have her own restaurant. This is her twelfth loan with MFP. She is part of a community bank and what she likes is that the people in her group are coordinated and organized. With the money that she is now requesting, she will build a "ramada" (a roof made of wood and branches) to protect her from the rains. She will also buy chairs and tables.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a roof for her food stand.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda H. is from the village of Acad, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 47 years old. Erlinda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste and boost food in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Erlinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Kim Thị's Group

texts.en:
"V. Kim Thị (0) is a 32 year-old woman who lives in the town of Đông anh - Hà nội. V. is the leader of a two-member loan group sponsored by SEDA. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Mạch Tràng (1). V. is married and has 3 school-aged children. To making a living, V. operates a family member's general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. V. has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2.000.000 VND a month from these activities. In 2007, V. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. V. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.028.000 VND from SEDA that she used to purchase additional products to sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 5.450.000 VND to purchase additional products to sell. This will be V.'s 5th loan from SEDA. V. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her house.

 

About the Other Borrowers in the Group: Đào Thị P. (10102140030) is a 35 year-old woman who is requesting a 5.450.000 VND loan to support her recycling business.

 

About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

 

 

V. Kim Thị (0) là 32 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông anh - Hà nội. V. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 2 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Mạch Tràng (1). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các P. thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các mặt hàng nhu yếu phẩm như dầu gội đầu, xà bông & kem đánh răng trong cộng đồng địa P.. V. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, V. kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND. Vào 2007, V. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. V. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.028.000 VND từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.450.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Đào Thị P. (10102140030) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.450.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là cung cấp dịch vụ tái chế. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anny Magdalena

texts.es:
Anny tiene 25 años de edad, se casó recientemente y tiene 2 hijos de 5 años de edad y nueve meses de nacido. Vive junto a su esposo y a su suegra en el anexo Guayaquil, distrito de Cayaltí, ubicado a hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales desde hace cuatro años aproximadamente. Ella nos comenta que la idea del negocio nació debido a la necesidad de instalarse definitivamente en la zona por los problemas de salud que presentaba su hijo mayor.

Anteriormente viajaba constantemente a la ciudad de Lima para traer mercadería y comercializarla en base a pedidos que le realizaban, pero ahora se dedica exclusivamente a la crianza de animales y a una pequeña bodega que está empezando a instalar.

Usualmente cría aves de corral y cuyes para luego venderlos a los negociantes que visitan la zona en donde vive. Eventualmente también los comercializa entre sus vecinos. Su cría de patos ha aumentado recientemente. Por lo que se ha visto en la necesidad de ampliar su negocio. Por ello se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de alimento balanceado.

Anny es una mujer activa y muy trabajadora, su mayor anhelo es poder ampliar su negocio para terminar de construir su casa y ofrecerle a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Anny, 25, was married recently; she has two children: a 5-year-old and a 9-month-old. She lives with her husband and her mother-in-law in Guayaquil Annex, Cayaltí district, which is an hour-and-a-half from Chiclayo. For approximately the last four years, she has raised small farm animals. She needed to establish herself in this line of work because she had to move to this area due to her oldest son’s health problems She used to travel to Lima constantly to bring merchandise to fill orders she had. However, now she is exclusively dedicated to raising animals and to a small store that she is starting to set up. She usually raises barnyard fowl and guinea pigs, which she then sells to merchants that visit the area where she lives. She sometimes sells to her neighbors, as well. Her duck production has increased recently so she needs to expand. She is asking Edpyme Alternativa for an initial loan of 1000 new soles that she will use to buy nutritionally balanced feed. Anny is an active, very hard-working woman. Her greatest wish is to have her business grow so that she can finish building her house and offer her children a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy nutritionally balanced animal feed.

loans.name: Laurencia

texts.en:
Mrs. Laurencia G. is 52 years old, married, and a resident of Minsubong, Tangub City. She is blessed with five adult-aged children. Her husband, Dionesio, is currently engaged in a bamboo furniture-making business and earns an average income of 5,000 PHP per month. Laurencia assists her husband in the preparation of the bamboo poles used for making the furniture. She also helps her husband market the finished bamboo furniture products. She joined PMPC two years ago. With a good repayment record, she was given a principal amount of 10,000 PHP for her fourth-cycle loan to increase the capital for their bamboo furniture-making business. The couple has a strong determination that someday their business will become known in other cities and in neighboring municipalities.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional capital for her bamboo furniture-making business

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia L. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Olivia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Olivia owns and operates a business, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Olivia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $150 a month from these activities.

In 2006, Olivia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Olivia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Olivia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 9th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Mother Blessing Group

texts.en:
Reuben F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Mother Blessing.  He is 35 years old, married, and has two children who are nine and 12 years old.  Reuben was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to a lack of support. For five years, Reuben has been selling jeans at the Red Light Market in Paynesville, which is near Monrovia.  He says he sells the jeans in an encouraging manner, which keeps customers returning.  One of the challenges he faces is that there are many competitors in the market. Reuben plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more jeans.  His goal is to open a beauty salon one day. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Reuben is the one holding the sign. 
 
About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more jeans.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more ampicillin capsules, paracetamol and folic acid for sale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is  married with four children and her children go to school. She owns a three roomed house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Mary takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. She works from her home and sells the drink by her self and sells to all categories of people both on retail and  wholesale. She works seven days a week. Mary receives at least 20 customers a day and  has been in this business for 10 years.  Business challenges include seasonality and the rainy season, which disturbs her because she works from a muddy place. Her main customers are older people and people from northern Uganda.  She has been with MCDT for many years, servicing her 14th loan. Mary wants to use this loan to buy more bags of cassava flour, maize bran and millet.  She aspires to see her business grow bigger and go directly to mills to buy millet, cassava flour and maize bran. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with low income women who want to boost their businesses.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cassava, millet and maize bran for making local brew

loans.name: Navuth

texts.en:
Mrs. Navuth M. and her husband Mr. Heng Hai (pictured together) live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1989 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. 

Mrs. Navuth M. sells vegetables and fruits in a Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a chef. He cooks for wedding ceremonies and other ceremonies in his village and sometimes in Phnom Penh. 

Under her wooden house is open airspace, so it’s difficult for her to keep the elements out. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to build a brick room under her wooden house.

loans.use: To build a brick room under her wooden house

loans.name: Perseveranda|

texts.es:
La señora Perseveranda D. de 72 años de edad está casada hace 39 años con el señor Ceferino Benítez de 72 años, el matrimonio cuenta con 10 hijos, todos mayores de edad, de los cuales dos hijos varones siguen viviendo con sus padre quienes le ayudan a su mamá en el manejo del negocio de venta de gallinas. 
Su marido trabaja en un aserradero, de esta forma todos se ayudan para llevar adelante los gastos familiares y el negocio.
La señora Perseveranda se inició en este negocio de ventas de gallinas caseras hace 12 años ya cuenta con clientela formada, además hace tortas y en época de verano tiene ventas de helados.
Solicita este préstamo para la  compra de gallinas, gansos patos, que le ofrecen en cantidad a buen precio y así tener  la oportunidad de hacer un buen negocio con la variedad de animales; así también comprar alimentos para engorde de los mismos; por otro lado desea adquirir productos como harina, azúcar e ingredientes para confitería para también incrementar su negocio de venta de tortas y bebidas, y al mismo tiempo incrementar su ingreso.
texts.en:
Perseveranda is 72 years old and has been married to 72 year old Ceferino for 39 years. They have 10 adult children, two of whom still live at home and help Perseveranda in her business; selling chickens. Her husband works at a sawmill. In this way they all pitch in to meet the family expenses. Perseveranda started her home-based chicken business 12 years ago and now has established customers. She also makes “tortas” and sells ice cream in the summer. She is asking for this loan in order to buy chicks, goslings, and ducklings, which she can buy at better prices in quantity, and feed for the animals. This will also allow her to do better business by offering a greater variety of animals. She also wants to buy flour, sugar, and other ingredients in order to increase her torta and drink business and increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Birds, feed, and supplies

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 40 years old and married. He is employed in an advocate firm and he runs a cafeteria. Because of his busy schedule, his wife assists him together with three other employees. His business is located in a busy area; hence, he gets many customers. 

Boniface is in a group called Vision in Faulu Kenya whose aim is to save money, share business ideas and guarantee each others loans. He has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy chairs and tables for his cafeteria. He hopes to open another cafeteria to meet his customers' high demands.

loans.use: To buy chairs and tables

loans.name: Aitbubu's Group

texts.en: Aitbubu K. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and breeds livestock. Her husband provides welding services at the hydroelectric station and when he has free time he helps Aitbubu with her business. In 2008, with the initial investment of 12,000 soms, Aitbubu bought eight farm animals and started to breed livestock. Now she has fifteen farm animals and, selling some of them after fattening, she makes 8,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Aitbubu wants to purchase seven farm animals for breeding. In the future she plans to open a pharmacy. Talantbek M., 39, is married and has four children: two sons and his older daughter are students and his second daughter is not yet in school. Eight years ago, with the initial investment of 2,000 soms, Talantbek bought three farm animals and started to breed livestock. Now he has eight farm animals and, selling some of them at a higher price after fattening, Talantbek makes 7,000 soms per month. He applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase ten sheep in order to increase the number of his livestock. Parida M. is the treasurer of the group; she is 43 and divorced with four children. In order to make money, two years ago she started to breed livestock. She started with an initial investment of 1,600 soms and, with that money, she bought two farm animals. In two years, she has increased the number of her livestock to ten and now, selling some livestock at a higher price after fattening, she makes 6,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase four farm animals in order to increase the number of her livestock. In the future she plans to save some money and start building a house for her children. Uulkyz K., 41, is married; her husband is an artist. They have two sons and a daughter: the first son and the daughter are students and the second son is not yet in school. In 2001, with an initial investment of 7,000 soms, Uulkyz bought a calf and started to breed livestock. Now she has nine farm animals and, selling some of them at a higher price after fattening, she makes 10,000 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase five farm animals in order to increase the number of her livestock. In the future she plans to open a poultry farm. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase seven farm animals for breeding

loans.name: Reyna Elizabeth

texts.es:
Reyna Elizabeth, tiene 27 años, resiD. en el Municipio D. Jucuapa, departamento D. Usulután,  es casada tiene un hijo D. 6 años y administra su negocio D. venta D. hot dog. 
Inicio el negocio hace 4 años, ella atienD. el negocio en un horario D. 8:00 am- 5:00 pm, con os ingresos del negocio apoya economicamente a la familia. Reyna solicita un préstamo para invertirlo en compra D. materiales como son: panes, jamón, pollo , mayonesa y bebidas, con esta inversión genera crecimiento al negocio, ofrece mas  productos a los clientes. 
Las aspiraciones son crecer como microempresaria, tener un negocio que le permita generar mayores ingresos para mejorar sistema D. vida para ella y la familia.
texts.en:
Reina Elizabeth is 27, lives in the Municipality of Jucapa in the Usulutan department, is married with a 6 year old son and runs her own hot dog sales business. She started the business 4 years ago and keeps a 8:00am to 5:00pm schedule. She uses the income from this business to support her family. Reina is requesting a loan to invest in goods such as: buns, ham, chicken, mayonnaise and beverages in order to grow the business by offering a wider variety of products to her customers. She aspires to continue growing as a micro-business owner, and to have a business that generates more income to improve life for her and her family.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase goods such as: buns, ham, chicken, mayonnaise and beverages

loans.name: Mario Antonio

texts.es: Mario Antonio tiene 55 años. Su actividad económica es un taller de carpintería. Hace más de 34 años que se dedica este negocio. Por lo que esta no es la primera experiencia con créditos, pues ha sido una gran experiencia. Inicio desde muy joven con este negocio pues su familia necesitaba de ingresos para mejorar su condición familiar. Mario siempre ha sido un hombre muy responsable, y le ha gustado ganarse el dinero de una manera muy decente y trabajadora.  El sueña con aumentar su negocio. el financiamiento es para la compra de materia prima necesaria ya que tiene muchos pedidos.
texts.en:
Mario Antonio is 55 years old and his economic activity is to operate his own carpenter shop. Mario has been dedicated to this business for more than 34 years. Therefore, this is not his first experience with loans – he has had great experience with them. He began the business when he was very young because his family needed income to improve their condition. Mario has always been a very responsible man and he has enjoyed earning money in a decent and hard-working manner. He dreams of augmenting his business. This loan is for buying necessary primary materials to fulfill the many work requests he has received.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING NECESSARY PRIMARY MATERIALS TO FILL CUSTOMER ORDERS AT HIS CARPENTER SHOP

loans.name: Kantuta Group

texts.es:
La Asociación Comunal “KANTUTA” es una asociación antigua que esta iniciando su crédito número catorce, es parte del Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación, tiene como presidenta a la señora Gimena.

Doña Gimena al igual que el resto de sus compañeras, es una socia que ha renovado vA. veces el crédito.  Su negocio es la venta de ropa de forma ambulante desde hace cinco años. El crédito que está solicitando actualmente es por la suma de Bs. 4500.- el mismo que invertirá en la compra de mercadería.

Por otro lado las integrantes de la asociación comunal esta conformado por diez mujeres y un varón. Tienen negocios diferentes, como: venta de ropa, venta de cosméticos, venta de comida, venta de garrafas, venta de batidos, venta de Tarjetas de teléfono y artículos varios, atención de Internet y trabajos en macramé.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Kantuta" is a long-established group that is starting its 14th loan cycle. It is part of the Pro Mujer central office in Villa Exaltacion. Gimena is the president of the group. Gimena, along with the rest of her group members, has taken loans on a number of different occasions. She is a street vendor who has been selling clothing for 5 years. She is now requesting a loan of 4,500 Bolivianos which she will invest in the purchase of merchandise. This central bank is comprised of 10 women and one man. They have a variety of businesses such as the sale of: clothing, cosmetics, food, carafes, milkshakes, telephone cards and other items, internet services and items made of macrame.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Bakhshi

texts.ru:
Bakhshi S. 29 let. On ne jenat i jivet v qorode Baku vmeste so so svoyey semyoy. Bakshi uje 3 qoda zanimayetsya etim biznesom prodaji odejdi. 

Etomu biznessu Bakshi  nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca. On toje ranshe prodoval odejdu a tak je veshi domashneqo upotrebleniya, potom otec Bakshi zabolel i bolshe ne smoq rabotat i on reshil prodoljit eqo bizness. Seychas  Bakhshi nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit noviy tovar novuyu odejdu dlya pereprodaji i razvitiya svoyeqo biznesa.
texts.en:
Bakhshi S. is twenty-nine years old, single and lives with his family in Baku. Following his father's example, Bakhshi is a salesman of household goods and apparel. He is applying for a loan to purchase new goods and clothes to increase sales and grow his business.
